title: emily maitlis shrugs bbc bias newsnight cummings
story: EMILY Maitlis fronted BBCs Newsnight tonight for the first time since she delivered a critical monologue about Boris Johnsons top aide.The presenter, who began last weeks show by stating that Dominic Cummings had broken lockdown rules and blasted the PMs blind loyalty, shrugged off claims shed been biased and didnt address the controversy at all.The programme this week looked at ongoing riots in the U.S. at the death of unarmed black man George Floyd.Maitlis made no further comment about her speech from last week.The BBC apologised the day after Maitlis tore into Cummings, saying her introduction did not meet impartiality standards.It added: Staff have been reminded of the guidelines.Editor Katie Razzall replaced her during the programme last Wednesday, with Maitlis saying she had asked for the night off.The Beeb has received more than , complaints in the week after the presenter criticised Cummings and the PM at the start of Tuesdays show.However, many are reportedly not about the presenters comments, and a source told the Daily Mail that some , were about the treatment of Maitlis.In her introduction to the BBC current affairs programme she said: Dominic Cummings broke the rules, the country can see that and its shocked the government cannot.She added that Cummings was the man, remember, who always got the public mood, he tagged the lazy label of elite on those who disagreed.The presenter was publicly reprimanded by bosses the next day for overstepping the mark.In a statement the corporation said: Newsnight risked giving the perception that the BBC was taking sides — or that the introduction constituted the presenter’s opinions, rather than a summary of the journalism which would follow.

title: test travellers airports opinion
story: Together with the staff, they provide the atmosphere, the le, the vitality.I started in the hospitality industry aged just  and it pains me to see the lobbies, restaurants and bars empty.Lockdown has been devastating for the tourism industry and I fear many businesses will not survive.For  years tourism has been part of my le and I have seen tremendous strides in Britain.We have world-class places to stay and to eat, earning the country a great reputation across the globe.But people from abroad will not be able to enjoy all we have to offerthe Government’s two-week travel quarantine starts next Monday.Under this restriction, anyone arriving in Britain will have to remain at the same address for two weeks.Spot-checks will be carried out to ensure any new arrivals are complying with isolation and fines will be imposed on those who flout it.No one coming here on ­holiday or on a short business trip is going to want to have to stay at one address for a ­fortnight after landing.It is to all intents and purposes a UK travel ban.This is why, along with  other travel companies, I have written to the Home Secretary, Priti Patel, calling for a ­dferent approach.The suggestion of “air bridges” would be a more sensible first step.Under this proposal, there would be agreements between Britain and other nations that are past their infection peak, which would allow ­people to move freely on arrival.In continental Europe, many countries are opening up to each other while blocking ­travellers from nations where they feel infection rates are still too high.Nations such as Denmark, which imposed a ban on ­people entering their country at the start of the pandemic, now let in a small number of other nationalities.When the infection rate here was high, we didn’t impose ­quarantines on people coming in from abroad. Yet now the rate is going down we are going to start doing so.This will seem perverse to the millions of us who have complied with ­lockdown laws while seeing planes arrive from highly infected nations.While we are effectively ­closing our borders, other nations are loosening their restrictions and opening up their markets to foreign travel.Many British companies have offices and subsidiaries overseas but the bosses of those firms won’t be able to visit their foreign-based business centres because they will face a two-week quarantine upon their .It gives totally the wrong impression to the world.The Prime Minister, Boris Johnson, had rightly ­campaigned for Brexit on the basis that Britain would be an outward-looking nation. That won’t be possible with international travel curtailed.Travellers will want to be reassured that airlines are ­taking measures to counter the spread of the virus, so ­temperature checks could be put into place at UK airports.That would tell the authorities which passengers have symptoms of the virus.It would be better than the two-week quarantine, which would only prolong a terrible ­nightmare for the British ­tourism industry upon which so many livelihoods depend. Around  per cent of the ­British workforce — four ­million people — have jobs either in or linked to tourism in this country.The industry is worth £billion to the economy but since lockdown it has stalled.The winter months are quiet, the spring has been spent in lockdown and the summer months are the most crucial.When the Government’s­ ­furlough scheme comes to an end, businesses will face some very tough ­choices.I am concerned about my ,-strong workforce and the last thing I would want to do is lay off staff. But I have got £.million going out the window every month due to lockdown.There are many businesses in this country that will not be able to weather the storm.Tourist destinations across the country, such as the Cotswolds and Bronte country in West Yorkshire, rely heavily on foreign visitors.At my London hotels, more than  per cent of the ­business comes from overseas.To make matters worse, while most European countries — including Italy — have reduced the two-metre social distancing rule to one metre, just about making operating possible, we continue to persist with the two-metre ruling.How can you go to a restaurant where everyone will be two metres apart  How will staff serve you at a distance Of course, every Covid- death we have seen is a ­tragedy and my heart goes out to the families of the victims.But the reality of the disease is that for the majority of the population, the virus is not deadly unless there are underlying health issues.I am  and had three bad weeks with the virus — a week of high temperature, a week of gradually losing the symptoms and a third week where I was like a wet rag.At my age, it takes four or five weeks to properly recover from it.We must not lose sight of the number of livelihoods that have already been seriously damaged and the millions of people who will find themselves out of jobs at the end of lockdown.For the tourism industry, which has already been brought to a standstill, the two-week quarantine would be the final nail in the coffin.Let’s keep Britain open, so there is hope for the future.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: elon musk leaving twitter spacex launch california
story: The Tesla CEO said hes leaving the  for a while in a cryptic Monday night tweet two days after achieving his longtime dream of launching two American astronauts into space.Off Twitter for a while, he said.Musks announcement caught the attention of the international hacktivist collective Anonymous, who vowed to fill the void left by the tech entrepreneur.Well take it from here, the group replied.Musks announcement comes on the heels of a big weekend for the industrial engineer.The SpaceX CEO teamed up with NASA to launch two astronauts from US soil into space for the first time in a decade on Saturday afternoon.The two-person crew took flight aboard SpaceXs Crew Dragon capsule and made its way toward the International Space Station, where they were scheduled to land Sunday morning just before : am, according to CNN.In a  interview, Musk revealed his ambitions to partner with NASA and to one day send astronauts into space.I think what were doing is critical to the future of NASA, Musk said at the time, according to the news outlet.Musks girlfriend, Canadian singer Grimes revealed a new nickname for their son after the couple was forced to rename him.Little X had his birth name changed to abide by Calornia law, which doesnt allow certain characters in names.After changing the babys name, Grimes took to Instagram and said having Roman numerals in it looks better.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: government spending furlough 1970s coronavirus
story: THE most extraordinary chapter in the story of modern Britain is drawing to a welcome close.Yet while lockdown eases, businesses re-open and millions bask on our sunny beaches, the skies are darkening in the distance.This gathering storm is not a potential second spike in infections - rather, it is an economic catastrophe.In the coming months, hard times could descend on Britain, fuelled by soaring unemployment and business failures.The Bank of England has already warned that we could be facing the worst slump for three centuries.In the current quarter, the economy could shrink by an incredible  per cent, as entire sectors like the hospitality trade and the travel business are devastated.“The unthinkable is now very much the reality,” says Stephen Phipson of the industrial body Make UK, whose latest survey found that  per cent of manufacturing firms are planning to lay off workers in the next six months.More than , bars and restaurants could remain permanently closed even when the lockdown is fully lted, while car sales in April were down  per cent compared to the same period last year.Under the energetic Rishi Sunak, the Government’s response has been to splash the cash in a determined - and understandable - attempt to keep the economy going.No less than £billion so far has been spent on the furlough job protection scheme, which pays  per cent of the wages of .million employees.Another £.billion has gone on a similar scheme for .million self-employed people.And a further £.billion has been swallowed up by business “bounce back” loans, half of which are unlikely to be repaid.Altogether coronavirus staff support could have cost the taxpayer over £billion by October, when furlough is due to end.But, far from phasing out state aid, the Government is likely to expand its scope over the coming months.The Treasury is now working on a plan called Project Birch, under which the Government will bail out a number of strategically important firms, either by providing large loans or by taking a stake in them.“Where a viable company has exhausted all options and its failure would disproportionately harm the economy, we may consider support on a last resort basis,” said a Treasury spokesman this week.Aerospace, manufacturing, steel production and car making are likely to be targeted.This policy would represent a huge change from the previous economic approach.Since Margaret Thatcher’s time, British governments have tried to avoid direct backing for companies, not least because such intervention is generally against European Union competition law.But the coronavirus has dramatically changed everything. Conventional wisdom about sound money and financial prudence has disappeared.Until recently the enemies of socialism, the Conservatives have now become converts to government action.Mrs Thatcher famously talked about “rolling back the frontiers of the state.”Now, in the wake of the Covid crisis, they have come sweeping forward once more.In the process, the public finances have taken a battering.In April the Government borrowed over £billion, a larger sum than for the whole of .The fiscal deficit is now projected to reach no less than £billion, perhaps even £billion in the worst case scenario.At the same time, more than million people — more than half the entire national workforce — are effectively on the state payroll.Even as lockdown eases, much of the economy has now been taken into the custody of the state.All this has to be paid for — and the bills cannot be met simply by printing more money.That is the route to a debased currency, soaring interest rates and hyperinflation.The reality is that massive state intervention is simply not sustainable except in an emergency.If printing money were the recipe for prosperity, then Zimbabwe would be the richest country on earth rather than mired in poverty.That is the lesson of history.If the Government carries on spending and intervening on a level that would have even made Jeremy Corbyn blush, then our country will be in real danger of sliding back to the dark days of the s.Gripped by industrial unrest and economic decline, Britain then was known as the “sick man of Europe”.Because of extravagant spending, the public finances were in a desperate state. In  inflation reached  per cent.The following year, Britain’s deficit was so enormous that the Government humiliatingly had to ask for a £.billion handout from the IMF.With the economy limping from one crisis to another, taxes soared, with the top rate on “unearned income” reaching  per cent.Some of the revenue was swallowed up in bailouts of troubled companies.In  the engine and car maker Rolls-Royce was rescued, followed by the Upper Clyde shipbuilders in  and volume motor manufacturer British Leyland in .Indeed, this was an era of institutionalised bullying by the strike-happy trade unions, who held the Government and the nation to ransom by flexing their industrial muscle.When Sir Horace Cutler, the Tory leader of the Greater London Council in the late s, was asked how many people work for London Transport, he replied, “about half of them.”In , which saw the Winter of Discontent, no fewer than million working days were lost to stoppages.At the peak of the disruption, bodies were left unburied and rubbish piled high in the street.The very fabric of society appeared to be falling part.“There is madness in the air,” recorded Bernard Donoghue, an aide to the Prime Minister Jim Callaghan.It was precisely the public’s revulsion at failed socialism and trade union irresponsibility that brought Margaret Thatcher to power in  on a  of reviving the economy.She achieved it by taming the unions, reinvigorating enterprise, restoring the work ethic and shrinking the Government.We need the same again today. All the good work of the last four decades will be undonewe slide back into the dependency culture, headed by a sprawling, sclerotic state machine.The only sure foundation on which to build a lasting recovery is by the wealth creation of the private sector.In practice that means the Government’s priority must be to encourage commerce and competition, not to dish out subsidies.So businesses should be urged to re-open as soon as possible, backed up by reductions in corporation tax and rates.Barriers to growth, like the strict social distancing limits, should be lted.At the same time, the Government should drop its plans to impose heavy-handed rules on quarantine for all travellers to Britain.It is a policy that will do nothing to protect public health but will cause huge damage to the economy, especially the travel industry.Similarly, Britain’s highly flexible labour market — the engine of the job creation miracle since  — must be maintained in the face of demands for more regulations.The best support that the Government can provide is not bailouts and bureaucracy, but a dynamic business environment along with a strong civic infrastructure, including modernised transport links and improved broadband.Soon after he became Prime Minister in , Jim Callaghan said: “We used to think we could spend our way out of recession. I tell you in all candour, that option no longer exists.”Under siege from inflation and the unions, his government was unable to abide by those sensible words.But as we come out of lockdown, their truth is more important than ever.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: girl arm blown off after gas explosion

title: coronavirus laws four weeks longer wait lockdown
story: The Health Secretary confirmed the change in writing at the bottom of his ministerial statement - and said it would allow the government more time to make crucial decisions on what to lt next.Previously they were reviewed every  days, but now that will be extended to every  days.In his written statement to MPs today, the Health Secretary said that he needed more time to look at whether easing any lockdown measures would have had an impact on the rate of transmission.The extra week will give more time to study the effects of changing the rules, and to make sure the R doesnt go above one.He said: To ensure that we are making future decisions about the lockdown at the right time, the maximum review period will change from  days to  days.This will allow decisions to align more closely with the period of time necessary to assess the impact of previous changes on key data feeds, including the R rate.The Government will also keep all the measures under continual review and will account to Parliament on an ongoing basis.The change means that the next lockdown review is expected to be now on June , instead.And it will also mean that there are only three chances left for Brits to get the green light for a summer break - before the end of the school holidays.Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland can all still follow their own exit timetable, and the move could further increase the lockdown dferences within the UK.Last week Boris Johnson announced that he would lt some lockdown measures.People in England can now meet in groups of up to six - as long as they are outside.Schools opened their doors to more pupils yesterday, alongside outdoor markets and car showrooms.More kids are set toto the classrooms in the coming weeks, and non-essential retail shops are set to open again from June  too.From July more rules are set to be relaxed, including the possibility that restaurants and pubs will be allowed to reopen.Hairdressers, hotels and other outlets are also pinning their hopes on a late summer opening.But today the PMs spokesperson insisted that any lting of lockdown rules is still dependent on how the country is doing in its battle against the virus at the time.The Government has said its not afraid to put in place local lockdownsnew outbreaks flare up.And Boris Johnson could put in a UK-wide shutdown againcases rise across the country.However, Mr Hancock has insisted the UKs new test and trace system will be efficient in tracking down every new case of the bug.Anyone who tests positive will be asked to hand over the phone numbers of people they have been in recent contact with.They will then be asked to isolate themselves for  days to make sure they dont pass on the bug to any more people.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: ibuprofen improve coronavirus survival rate 80 preventing serious cases
story: IBUPROFEN could be the key to treating severe cases of coronavirus, doctors hope.The cheap painkiller could help improve survival rates by up to  per cent, and reduce the need for patients to be treated in intensive care.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesIt comes after controversy early on during the pandemic, over fears the anti-inflammatory may make Covid- worse.French health minister Olivier Veran suggested the drug could worsen infections, and prompted Sir Patrick Vallance, Englands chief scientic adviser, to tell Brits to take paracetamol instead. The NHS also removed ibuprofen as a suggested treatment for mild cases. But, a subsequent study suggested the drug did not worsen or improve patients conditions.Now, a team of scientists in London are starting a new clinical trial to seethe anti-inflammatory could in fact help speed up the recovery in some patients by reducing serious side effects.Its hoped the drug could lead to shorter hospital stays and fewer people ending up in intensive care units .Animal studies have shown that the treatment can increase survival rates by  per cent.Prof Mitul Mehta, whos leading the trial at KCL, told PA: This is very promising, but of course it is an animal study, so we want to translate that really compelling result into humans.Its a trial for patients with Covid- disease to seegiving them an anti-inflammatory drug - a specic form of ibuprofen - will reduce the respiratory problems they have.Prof Mehta stressed that the trial was for patients already in hospital, not those with mild or suspected Covid-.Volunteers will be selected from patients who are in hospital, but that are not so ill they need intensive care.Prof Mehta said: If we can reduce their symptoms at that stage we have a number of benefits. We could reduce the amount of time someone spends in hospital - they might recover quicker and go home, thats obviously a fantastic outcome.We also might be reduce the degree of respiratory distress so that it can be managed in the hospital setting, without needing to go to ICU, and thats a fantastic outcome as well.Theoretically, this treatment, given at this time, should be beneficial.But, of course, this is based on animal studies. Its based on case reports, we need to do a trial to show that the evidence actually matches what we expect to happen.The Liberate trial is being carried out at KCL as well as Guys and St Thomass NHS Foundation Trust, along with the pharmaceutical organisation, the SEEK Group.Half of the patients taking part will be given standard care, while the other half will receive standard care as well as the special ibuprofen formulation.Prof Matthew Hotopf, director of the NIHR Maudsley Biomedical Research Centre, said: This highly innovative therapeutic approach seeks to rapidly advance a potentially important new treatment.If successful, the global public health value of this trial would be immense given the low cost and availability of this medicine.Earlier this year, at the start of the pandemic, there was some controversy over the use of ibuprofen after a French health minister advised against using it.Scientists in the UK launched a review and the NHS removed the drug as a recommended treatment for mild cases. But the findings showed ibuprofen does not make Covid infections better or worse.The Commission on Human Medicines expert working group concluded: There is currently insufficient evidence to establish a link between use of ibuprofen and susceptibility to contracting Covid- or the worsening of symptoms. To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: aldi shopper ban basket pint milk
story: Lee Nutbean popped into the Plymouth shop last week to get the item and says he was refused entry without a basket under company policy.The disgruntled shopper, , called customer services and was told to head back to the store and tell the manager it wasnt a policy he could enforce.But at the shop he was told having a basket is a local decision [the manager] has made for the store, and was subsequently banned.Mr Nutbean complained to the helpline again and was advised to speak with the manager to bring an end to the situation.He said: The manager then explained how having a basket is a local decision he has made for the store, as it makes things easier for them at the till, and this decision still stands.I told him I was getting confused as customer services are saying I dont need a basket. story: The PMs spokesman said today the press conferences were being dialled back because the UK has entered a dferent phase of the pandemic.The spokesman said the Government was absolutely committed to keeping the country updated and the press conferences would continue to happen during the week.He said: From this week, the press conferences will be on weekdays only – so no longer on Saturdays and Sundays.The PM will take a press conference every week alongside… the scientic and medical experts.Others will be led by secretaries of state, alongside scientic and medical experts where relevant.He said the change was because the numbers who are viewing at weekend do tend to be signicantly lowerThe sht away from weekend press briefings - which have happened every day since March  - comes after senior Tories told the MailOnline the daily talks were bloody boring and the PM should scale them down to normalise the country.They said having updates every day was creating a pressure for the Government to make announcements, whether there was anything to say or not.One senior Tory MP said: I think there is a very, very good argument to say suspend the press conference and just have one a week on the track and trace stuff.A press conference without an announcement is just pretty bl**dy boring.To start with we all tuned in avidly. title: lidl shopper stunned swimsuit top
story: Lynn Ruane, who was dressed in a swimsuit and a sarong, was asked to wear a dferent top next time she visited the Dublin store.It came as temperatures soared to C across Britain and Ireland in what has been the hottest Spring ever recorded for the UK.Ms Ruane, who is an Independent Senator in Seanad Éireann, shared her frustration on Twitter, writing: @lidl_ireland wants me to wear a dferent top to shop there apparently.Asme wearing a swimsuit for a top in the summer is any dferent to any other little tank top Id wear.Get a grip. Men walking around in vests showing just as much skin.The Senator later admitted that maybe you could see too much of her bottom half.She added: I went home. Checked the mirror.Berated myself that maybe you could see too much of my upper thigh through my sarong .Lidl Ireland were quick to respond to the post, with Ruanne later adding: @lidl_ireland have communicated with me very promptly, apologised for the incident and Im glad they will be communicating their policy with the store and security involved.A spokesperson for Lidl Ireland revealed the worker was from a third party security company and not part a Lidl employee.The spokesperson said in a statement: We have been made aware of a situation in a store regarding an inappropriate comment to a customer regarding her clothing.This comment was made by a member of Lidl’s third party security company and not by a Lidl employee.In an effort to manage social distancing there are increased levels of security in stores and many of these guards are not overly familiar with store policies.We have been in touch with the customer to apologise directly and we have contacted the company to ensure that all third party staff contracted to Lidl are re-briefed on policies.

title: china delayed coronavirus data saved thousands weeks who
story: CHINA delayed the release of coronavirus data that could have saved lives for two weeks, a leaked WHO report has claimed. The news comes after months of speculation about attempts by the countrys regime to cover up the extent of the outbreak in the beginning.The WHO publicly praised Chinas cooperation at the time, but the plaudits were reportedly only part of an attempt to abstract more information from the government.A report compiled by the World Health Organisation describes how three government labs succeeded in sequencing the viruss genome over a week before it was published on January , the Associated Press reported.Sequencing was an essential step towards understanding the behaviour of the virus and developing a vaccine, and was first accomplished by the Wuhan Institute of Virology on January .Interviews and internal documents reportedly suggested that the delay releasing the data was caused by tight controls on information as well as competition within the Chinese healthcare system.Even after the data had been released, China reportedly delayed for another two weeks as the WHO tried to obtain from them detailed data on patients and the number of coronavirus infections.Maria Van Kerkhove, a US epidemiologist who is now the WHOs technical lead in the fight against coronavirus, said in one meeting: Were going on very minimal information.Its clearly not enough for you to do proper planning.Speaking to the Associated Press, Ali Mokdad, a professor at the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation at the University of Washington, said it was obvious that we could have saved more livesswter action had been taken.The WHO publicly praised Chinas cooperation at the time, but the plaudits were reportedly only part of an attempt to abstract more information from the government.In another meeting, Dr Gauden Galea, the WHOs most senior official in China, said: Were currently at the stage where yes, theyre giving it to us  minutes before it appears on [state media].In a speech at the Wealth Health Assembly last month, Chinese President Xi Jinping claimed China had always provided information to the WHO in a most timely fashion.He also pledged billion over the next two years to help fight the ongoing coronavirus pandemic.Todays report comes after officials in Wuhan, where the outbreak began late last year, said that no new cases of the virus had been found after a round of testing that reached .million of the citys million people.It also follows earlier reports that China threatened the WHO into delaying warnings about Covid- while it stockpiled medical supplies.

title: meghan markle complains kate snaps fingers palace running
story: The actress has told pals she had little support when she was shredded by the media - whereas Kate has the backing of the royals when she faces negative reports, according to the DailyMailIt comes after society bible Tatler ran a cover story about Kate - headlined Catherine the Great - which claimed she was feeling exhausted after Prince Harry and Meghan stepped back from their royal duties in March.Last week Kensington Palace issued a statement on the Tatler article saying it “contained a swathe of inaccuracies and  representations”.Now, a friend of Meghans has told the Mail: Meghan said Kensington Palace never once came to her defence when she was being shredded by the media.Now Kate gets a bit of negative press, and the Palace comes out in less than  hours to rebuke the claims made against her.Meghan reportedly told pals she had been plagued by negative stories, but despite pleas from Prince Harry, the Palace has done nothing to interfere.This was behind the couples decision to quite their royal duties and move to LA, it is claimed.The friend said: This is really a slap in the face for Harry because he repeatedly asked for an updated, revised media policy - or at least a conversation about his concerns.All fell on deaf ears, and then Kate comes along, snaps her fingers and gets an outpouring of support.Meghan says its just so telling.She explained this was one of the main reasons why she and Harry said their goodbyes to royal le - the lack of support and complete disregard for the pain and anguish Meghan suffered while being crucied in the media.Meghan said, rather than backing her, she was made to feel like she was asking too much, expecting too much, when all she wanted was support from the powers that be.It comes after claims that Kate and William are taking legal action against Tatler. The article made reference to eating disorders, suggesting Kate has become “perilously thin like Princess Diana”.Kate and William have reportedly demanded the magazine remove its online profile of Kate.And a royal source said the article caused immense unnecessary pain for Kate.Last year, it was claimed that the so-called Fab Four split when Harry accused Prince William and Kate of not supporting Meghan ahead of their wedding.

title: new zealand scrap social distancing monday boosting hopes rest world
story: NEW Zealand is set to scrap social distancing from next week after  days without a single new case of coronavirus.The country has just one active case of COVID- in the country today and has recorded only  deaths and , cases since the pandemic began.Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern had previously said June  was the latest a decision to loosen remaining social distancing restrictions would come, and on June  the Government would reconsider the settings of alert level .But after speaking with director-general of health Dr Ashley Bloomfield this week, Ardern said the country could be in level  as early as June , as long as we keep seeing the results were seeing now.She said: We are exceeding our expectations in terms of our progress, which is a fantastic position to be in.Our strategy of go hard, go early has paid off.Gong to level  means all social distancing measures and limits on mass gatherings will be lted, but borders will remain closed to the outside world   The South Pacic island nation of . million people had introduced a strict lockdown and enforced it for nearly seven weeks, despite there being no signs an epidemic was taking hold.Most businesses were shut and everyone except essential workers had to stay at home.Ms Ardern added: We will be one of the first countries in the world toto this level of normality so quickly.Meanwhile in the UK daily coronavirus cases are falling to some of the lowest rates since the outbreak with the latest daily cases standing at , and the overnight death toll of , with nearly , dead so far. Health Secretary Matt Hancock said the coronavirus outbreak has had a very signicant impact on Britain.He told tonights No  briefing that it underlined the importance of developing a test and trace system.It is undoubtedly true that we have had a very signicant impact from this virus - there is no doubt about that, he said.We have been learning all the way through it how best to deal with that.The test and trace system that we have built over the past few weeks is one of the lessons that comes out of it - the absolute vital importance of having a system that is big enough to be able to trace as many of those who tested positive as possible.As the country emerges out of the worst of the pandemic, it has relaxed lockdown to allow people to meet up outside.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: politician topless government zoom call turned camera off
story: -year-old senator Martha Lucia Micher started getting changed during a May  meeting with members of the National Regeneration Movement political party, the Bank of Mexico, and journalists.Screenshots from the meeting originally meant to discuss the impact of the coronavirus pandemic were leaked by an unknown attendee.Sen. Micher apologised for the incident after it did the rounds on social media and she was mercilessly trolled by creeps and perverts.The senator took a strong stance against the bullying and came out swinging, saying she is proud of her body and refuses to be objectied.She said: “I am Malu Micher, and I am not ashamed to have shown part of my intimacy by accident, because it is exactly the notion that a woman is ‘just her body’ that has allowed and fomented the objectication of women against which I have always fought.“I am a woman of  years of age who has breastfed four children, three of whom are today professional and responsible men, and I feel proud of my body for having nourished them.“I am a woman who has fought for the left for almost  years and who has occupied ious public roles in my fervent commitment for the defence of human rights, I am a woman who is not ashamed of her body, I love it and I take care of it.”Many of her colleagues and fellow politicians have come out to show solidarity with the senator.Fellow senator Ricardo Monreal Avila wrote: “In view of the attacks against her, a product of a mishap during a virtual meeting, we endorse our fellowship. Morals and integrity will always be stronger than infamy and assaults.”Another senator, Maria Elena Morena posted: “The rubbish stinks in the senate and on social media. Our political and party dferences should have limits.”Fellow party member Martha Tagle wrote: “I will investigate and sanction those responsible for taking and leaking these photos. The violence to which you were subjected cannot go unpunished.”According to local media, parliament has stated that they will take legal action against those who publish photos of the incident on social media.Sen. Micher is not the first person to suffer a Zoom blunder.A recent Zoom that included Brazilian president Jair Bolsonaro also hosted a naked man, and a Spanish news anchor was caught cheating on his girlfriend when a naked woman walked across the room during a video call on live TV.

title: government wins vote against vote from home
story: Furious MPs took selfies as they waited in the queue for  minutes, branding the system a farce.Speaker Sir Lindsay Hoyle and his officials were left repeatedly shouting instructions at MPs as social distancing measures required them to join a queue, keep two metres apart, walk through the Commons chamber and announce their vote.The queue stretched for several hundred metres, snaking through Westminster Hall and running to Portcullis House, the newer part of the parliamentary estate.They were compared to the huge queues for IKEA that were seen this week. Some shoppers were forced to wait for three hours to get into the store.It came as the Government dropped procedures which allowed MPs to vote online and speak remotely via Zoom, thereby requiring them to appear in person to take part.Conservative Karen Bradley, who chairs the Procedure Committee, moved an amendment to keep remote voting in place in the coming weeks, with several Conservative MPs rebelling to support the proposal.But it was defeated by  votes to , majority , following a -minute ision.MPs later approved the Governments motion to only allow them to vote in person by  votes to , majority .After Ms Bradleys amendment to the Governments motion was pushed to a vote, Sir Lindsay said the queuing system would continue as it is the only method that is compatible with Government-set requirements and those from Public Health England.As some MPs dallied, Sir Lindsay could be heard telling them: Why are we not keeping up  There are other members waiting.Some MPs also appeared confused at the new voting procedures.Some Conservative MPs attempted to exit the chamber via the wrong door, despite being told by the Speaker moments earlier which way to go.DUP MP Jim Shannon initially walked up to the noes column, before correcting himself and walking through the ayes section.During the debate, Sir Lindsay appealed for a bit of give and take from the Government and opposition parties to ensure all MPs can continue to vote.Commons Leader Jacob Rees-Mogg said he would table a motion on Wednesday which would enable MPs unable to attend Parliament on medical grounds to take part in certain proceedings, including questions, urgent questions and ministerial statements.Mr Rees-Mogg said: The stopgap of a hybrid Parliament was a necessary compromise during the peak of the virus, but by not being here the House has not worked effectively on behalf of constituents.He added he expects teething problems with the new voting system which involves queuing, adding it will be some time before our proceedings are fully restored.Labours Chris Bryant joked have you ever been to Alton Towers to which Mr Rees-Mogg replied: Indeed, yes I have, I took my sister Annunziata there many years ago.Enough of my reminisces because it is important that we protect, preserve, prioritise our parliamentary democracy, it has to continue regardless of the disease that is title: tiktok mum pours milk over toddler
story: The clip shows two women dancing to Robbie Doherty  Keees’ song ‘Pour The Milk’ in a garden before emptying their mugs onto the frightened tot’s head.The bewildered infant, who has a dummy in his mouth and is wearing a nappy ends up covered in the liquid.The tot appears to burst into tears before turning and staggering away confused.More than , TikTokkers have made videos to the  dance song with the lyrics saying “and instead I pour the milk” - before pouring cereal and milk into a pal’s mouth.But the seemingly cruel take at the tot’s expense drew fury from viewers demanding the adults be reported.One version of the video shared on Facebook has been viewed more than , times.And the clip posted on Twitter has been seen more than , times.Outraged viewers have condemned the two adults for their prank.One user blasted: “Disgusting - that poor baby. title: two metre social distancing economy
story: IN parks and on pavements up and down the land you cannot escape the numerous signs telling us to stand at least two metres apart.It has become the new normal — stand back, give people space, don’t spread the virus. And Britain has been very good at it.But as we slowly move out of lockdown with thoughts of shopping, seeing our friends and family, and a cool drink in a pub garden, how effective this two-metre rule actually is has become a new national obsession.Many are starting to ask: Do we really need to keep a two-metre gap  Could it in fact be ONE metre  It may sound trivial, a metre is still too far to hug, kiss, even to shake hands with friends and loved ones.But for many businesses which rely on allowing people to gather more closely — theatres, restaurants, pubs, to name but a few — cutting the official social distance in half could be the dference between keeping afloat or going under.The official advice of the World Health Organization is that one metre is sufficient, a belief shared by the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control.The Danes changed their position three weeks ago to one metre and most of the European countries’ public health officials advise one metre in certain circumstances.Now a new study by the WHO has found that while a two-metre distance reduced the risk of the virus being passed on to . per cent, a one-metre gap only increased the chance of transmission to . per cent.So a small risk either way, but enough to justy potentially endangering some of the industries we both enjoy and, for many thousands, rely upon for work. I have been asking for a couple of months how that distance was established, yet its origins are very obscure.It seems to go back to research on the distance between beds in the old-fashioned Nightingale wards in the s. It has become a folklore of infection control and public health, until people have started asking questions about it today.Experiments about the distance droplets travel have been conducted under such articial conditions that they are not applicable to everyday lives.Laboratory air is articially still, whereas air is not still, even when you are sitting in a room with all the windows and doors closed. Air flow breaks up the particles from a sneeze or a cough and they tend to fall pretty quickly on to your clothes or face.The serious risk of infection is when you get up to half a metre away from somebody with Covid- who sneezes or coughs.But the dference between one metre and two metres is the dference between a very small risk and a very tiny risk.To the economy, the dference is a radical one. Shting from two metres to one metre would allow us to get back to something close to business as usual. If you imagine a two-metre circle drawn around any inidual, that takes up  and a half square metres.When you come down to a one-metre safe zone, it is only . square metres. So you could get four times as many people into any given space. With the two-metre rule,  per cent of pubs and bars say it wouldn’t be economically viable to reopen. With four times as many customers, only small pubs would face dficulties.The current approach doesn’t grasp that town centres are leisure destinations and that people won’t go outit is an unpleasant experience. Shoppers want to have a coffee, lunch, try on clothes, it is a social activity with their friends.I believe that cinemas are safe to reopen and that perhaps we might be able to allow some fans back into football stadiums to cheer on their teams again.In a typical cinema, where seating is tiered and there is air conditioning,you do happen to be coughing out, the thermal heat from the bodies should rise it up out into the air conditioning system.Allowing fans to attend football matches again would be a challenge, because of the congestion going into the stadium.They would have to carefully plan entrance and exit times and leave every other seat vacant unless there is a family group, so you would probably be playing in front of a stadium which is  per cent full.I may be part of a faction that favours one metre, but the consensus is that the risk of transmission outside is very low.So joggers don’t have to go into the road to avoid getting too close to someone  on the pavement — because their slipstream will mean the droplets will probably stick to them anyway.The best way to reduce the risk of the virus spreading is a good standard of hygiene, sanitising your hands at the end of a journey and after eating.If you are involved in a lot of customer interactions, such as supermarket checkouts, Perspex barriers are helpful.The Government has taken so much flak on easing lockdown restrictions that they seem to be reluctant to get into a fight on this one. But we need to remember that interrupting the transmission of the virus is not about rules and their enforcement.It is about assessing the risk at each inidual venue, because sticking to two metres in all cases poses a risk to our economic health.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: nightclub coronavirus ibiza coronavirus wayne lineker
story: IBIZA club boss Wayne Lineker has revealed he has had to shut down his dancefloor to fend off coronavirus.Lineker revealed a raft of strict new measures to protect partygoers from Covid- as nightclubs search for ways to adapt amid the pandemic.Wayne - brother of footballer Gary Lineker - unveiled new measures for his venues while speaking on This Morning.It comes as the Spanish nightle industry has drawn up a new raft of measures to allow clubs to open post-coronavirus lockdown.The party boss boasted he has made his venues - such as the famous Linekers bar in Ibiza - safe for staff and holidaymakers as Spain looks to kick-start tourism.Measures such as shutting down the dancefloor, two metre distances between sunbeds, hand sanitiser on the tables, staff wearing masks and disinfectant mists will be in place.He said: Theres not going to be a dancefloor this year which is a shame but current times make sure thats not a possibility.We just want to be very safe for the clients.Wayne added they also have a strong security team to try and make sure guests keep social distance even while drunk.They will be very polite and very well mannered in the way they address the people, he said.Spain is expected to reopen its borders to international tourists from July - but nightclubs around the world are looking for new ways to reopen.Wayne is confident that Linekers can reopen on July  to welcome the seasons first guests.Meanwhile, Spains National Federation of Leisure and Entertainment Businesses have drawn up a new raft of measures for venues to crackdown on coronavirus.Plans recommend all clubbers will have to wear facemasks and will have to wash their hands as they enter and leave.Customers will also not be able to mix drinks, and they will only be served with disposable straws.Seating areas will also be reserved, while markings on the floor will help people keep their social distance.Drinks will have to be ordered on an app to avoid clusters of people at busy bars.And while Wayne has closed off his dancefloor, the new guidelines say you can have one - but as long as social distancing is enforced.The beloved nightspots in destinations such as Ibiza and Magaluf will be able to reopen again once Spain begins phase three of its lockdown easing plan.Other nightclub measures could include QR codes being scanned on the door to keep track of who goes into the venue.South Korea is rolling out this scheme that also includes churches, gyms, concert halls and restaurants to help trace coronavirus cases.The persons information is logged by the government and held for four weeks before being deleted.It will allow anyone who has potentially come in contact with a coronavirus case to get notied so they can tested.It is unclear when nightclubs and pubs will begin to fully reopen in Britain, but pressure is growing to review the two metre rule.A new study has suggested just one metre may be almost as effective at combating the spread of coronavirus.Meanwhile, there is hope for summer holidays to party hotspots in Spain as the UK considers easing plans for a -day quarantine.It is hoped the two week legally-mandated isolation could be scrapped by the end of June.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: keeping pubs afloat sun says
story: WE would put up with a lot to get back to the pub. We’re just not sure we’ll ­recognise the experience under the ­Government’s plans for them.Perspex screens protecting staff who will barely interact with punters ­anyway. Drinks ordered by app, then wordlessly collected from the bar.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesStrict limits on numbers, with the dubious two-metre distancing rigidly observed. Costly new ventilation systems supposedly dispersing the virus.Hardly a cosy and inviting prospect. Butit keeps our pubs afloat, great. We dearly hope it will last only a few weeks.The signs are looking up. Oxford Professor Carl Heneghan reckons our death rate will be at “normal” levels next week, with zero Covid deaths by July.Another eminent professor says there is no ­evidence a second wave will hit us.Even a holiday looks a little more likely. EasyJet will fly to  per cent of its destinations by August.Yet half of Britain remains hooked on the lockdown, unwilling to venture out, to narrow the two-metre rule . . . terried of even the gentlest easing of rules.And many are better off than before. In April we paid off a record £.billion of personal debt and tripled our monthly savings to £.billion. That’s thanks to generous furlough payments, mortgage holidays and saved daily expenses.Far too many think this surreal situation is sustainable. It is not. A huge crash is coming when the bailouts end.The faster weto normality, the less horric its impact will be. WHEN is quarantine not quarantine  When you can still go out — even on the bus.This contradictory fudge is, incredibly, what the Government has come up with, caught between those wanting to lock visitors up for a fortnight and those, like The Sun, who believe that would wreck tourism, our economy and vast numbers of jobs.Quarantining already looks bonkers at this stage. This half-measure is a joke:Restrictive enough to deter most travellers, but not enough to prevent badly infected arrivals from passing Covid on. And farcical enough to further erode trust in the Government.IT should not take George Floyd’s appalling murder and the ensuing protests to remind the world that black lives matter.That sentiment was also why it was vital for Public Health England to find out exactly why BAME people have a higher risk of dying from Covid — and to recommend counter-measures.Why didn’t it  The PHE report just restates what we knew. It failed even to allow for obesity or a victim’s job — both crucial factors. Now a Government minister is having to probe it all further.Another PHE shambles.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: urban fox snout shorter scavenge bins
story: The animal is known for its cunning but its head and brain is becoming smaller as it adapts to le among humans, researchers say.And the males have become metrosexual — shrinking to almost the same size as the vixens.An international team compared  skulls of red foxes from London and the countryside.Researcher Dr Kevin Parsons, of the University of Glasgow, said: “We saw urban foxes had a smaller brain size capacity but also a dferent snout shape that would help them forage within urban habitats.“There was also less of a dference between males and females in urban foxes.”He says the ergence of city dwellers from their country cousins also helps explain the evolution of dogs from wolves to our domesticated companions.The number of red foxes in urban areas of England has soared from , to , in  years.They are often brazen around humans, even approaching them for food.Dr Parsons added: “Urban red foxes are becoming more similar to domesticated dogs as they adapt to their city environment.”The similar size of the sexes brings them closer to many domesticated animals.Researcher Dr Andrew Kitchener, from National Museums Scotland, said many of the changes would have been similar in the initial phases of domestication for our pets such as dogs and cats.He added: “So, adapting to le around humans actually primes some animals for domestication.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: school shutdown poor kids 16 months behind
story: THE shutdown of schools could leave poor kids  months behind better-off classmates, a study found.By the end of primary school, they are on average . months behind richer pupils.This gap could widen to as much as  monthsschools stay shut until September, the Education Endowment Foundation and Sutton Trust found.The study said it was “highly unlikely” a short-term catch-up strategy could make up the time.EEF’s Prof Becky Francis said poor kids were “particularly impacted” by not being in school.The report states: “The projections suggest that school closures will widen the attainment gap between disadvantaged children and their peers, likely reversing progress made to narrow the gap since .It adds: “It is highly likely that the gap will have widened when pupilsto school, eventhe strongest possible mitigatory steps are put in place.“There is a risk that high levels of absence after schools formally reopen poses a particular risk for disadvantaged pupils.”Ministers faced down militant trade unions to order the phased reopening of primary schools from Monday –  weeks after they were shut down.But a string of mainly northern councils are refusing to open their schools until later in the month.All primary school kids are expected to spend some time in class before the summer holidays next month. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email Matt Hancock declared black lives matter as he spoke about a devastating report which has laid bare the way that BAME communities are much worse affected by coronavirus.But despite his acknowledgement of the dreadful death toll from covid- among these communities, the Health Secretary did not announce any concrete proposals to help protect people affected.Under pressure to explain why there were no recommendations being announced today, Mr Hancock insisted the government had already taken action because it’s been clear right from the start.He explained that the first four deaths of doctors were all people from BAME backgrounds.He said: “It really struck me there was clearly a disparity and we’ve seen that disparity.” He added: “Right across the world people are angry about racial injustice - and I get that. Black lives matter”. But despite invoking the slogan which has dominated headlines in recent weeks as protests continue in the US and around the world following the death of George Floyd at the hands of Minneapolis police, Mr Hancock did not announce any new measures to protect against those communities most at risk from coronavirus. Hancock said those from BAME communities worried about ing to work should consult the safety at work guidance published by the Government. The number one thing Iaposd say for anybody in a higher risk group, the most important thing to do is stringently follow the social distancing guides, including the work on social distancing at work that has been published, he said. There is specic guidance for social distancing in the workplace. He confirmed that Equalities Minister Kemi Badenoch had been tasked with leading on the Governmentaposs response to the PHE report and what further could be done. Mr Hancock said: There is much more work to be done and the report shows that. But he could not give a timetable for recommendations to protect those at risk - particularly BAME workers on the frontline.The Public Health Englandreview found people of Bangladeshi ethnicity had around twice the risk of death as people of white British ethnicity, while people of Chinese, Indian, Pakistani, other Asian, Caribbean and black ethnicity had between a % and % higher risk of death. Professor Gurch Randhawa, Professor of Diversity in Public Health and Director of the Institute for Health Research at the University of Bedfordshire, says the report fails to make recommendations to improve the situation it documents, despite this being its original brief: “Sadly, but predictably, the report does a wonderful job of setting out the inequalities experienced by dferent communities under COVID-, but that is just about as far as it goes. Unfortunately, the report makes no recommendations as to how the situation should be addressed, even though providing such recommendations was a key part of its original remit. “The report is completely silent on the obligations of government and other public sector bodies to ensure COVID- policy responses adhere to the Public Sector Equality Duty. It is also silent on the urgent need for Equality Impact Assessments to inform all future policy planning to ensure protection for all members of the public, regardless of race or ethnicity. “This omission can best be described as a lack of humility and honesty in learning from our past actions. It is vital that the government learns lessons from its early missteps in order to prevent a rise in health inequality being one of the principal outcomes of the COVID- pandemic.” The report prompted a backlash against the governmentaposs handling of the crisis. Windrush campaigner Patrick Vernon accused the Government of taking a colour blind approach in tackling Covid-. The former Hackney Labour councillor, said a public inquiry needed to be launched to fully assess the impact of coronavirus on BAME communities. He said: What we need now is a public inquiry with evidence from frontline staff, families and experts to give context to the data. He said the PHE review highlighted the contribution made by BAME people in UK society as he pointed to the large number of deaths among frontline workers who were from those communities.  To help bereaved families who have lost loved ones to Covid-, Mr Vernon launched a fundraising page on GoFundMe to provide grants for memorial events, which has so far raised more than £,. Mr Vernon accused the Government of failing to undertake a proper impact assessment into how Covid- affected BAME groups, saying this was also the case when looking at the impact on care homes.  The report highlights that BAME lives matter, and the Government should no longer take the colour blind approach any more, he said.  At the beginning of the pandemic they said coronavirus does not discriminate, but the impact of it does discriminate - they didnapost look at the risks that it posed on BAME people. The PHE report said the relationship between ethnicity and health is complex and likely to be the result of a combination of factors. For example, BAME people are likely to be at increased risk of acquiring the infection due to the fact they are more likely to live in urban areas, in overcrowded households, in deprived areas, and have jobs that expose them to higher risk, the study said.

story: NewsBoy marks first birthday as donor law comes into force after his own transplantEXCLUSIVE Tommy Collins has become a symbol of hope for Max and Keiras Law through his liver transplant, which was initially pushed back because staff at Kings College Hospital in London were so busy battling coronavirusShareCommentsByJeremy Armstrong:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsTommy Collins is a symbol of hope for Max and Keiras Law" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA baby celebrated his first birthday on the day Max and Keira’s Law came into force – after a le-saving organ transplant from his dad. Now Tommy Collins is a symbol of hope for the Mirror-backed scheme, in which everyone in England is a potential donor after they die unless they opt out. Among the first to praise the new legislation were Tommy’s parents Alfie Collins and Maisie Davies. Dad Alfie,  – who donated a slice of liver for his son’s op – said: “We’d waited so long for a donor and in the end it felt right that I underwent the transplant for my boy. Actually I was a perfect match. The liver will grow in Tommy like a normal one and my own will regenerate inside me. It’s the body’s only organ that can do so.” He said the transplant has “transformed” le for Tommy, whose rare liver disease made him produce too much ammonia. That affected his brain, leaving him subject to fits.The transplant was conducted at King’s College Hospital in London on April  after being postponed because staff there were so busy battling the coronavirus crisis. There was a late drama when another donor was found as Alfie lay unconscious ready for the operation but surgeons opted to proceed after two earlier ones had proved to be unsuitable.Mum Maisie, , said she will never forget seeing “my two boys” head off for the operating theatre. “I prayed they would be safe,” added Maisie, who gave birth to Tommy at St Thomas’ Hospital where she is a receptionist. “This has given Tommy a new lease of le.”

story: NewsFin whale that washed up on UK beach with punctured lung was hit by shipThe Big Blue Ocean Cleanup examined the body and confirmed it had been hit by a commercial ship whilst out at sea before it washed up to Holland-on-Sea, EssexShareCommentsByPaige Ingram:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsExperts moving the whale from the beach " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA Fin whale which washed up on a UK beach had suffered a punctured lung after being hit by a ship, it has now been confirmed. Police and Ocean authorities worked together to remove the carcass from the wateraposs edge in Holland-on-Sea, Essex, on Friday as people flocked to the beach. The juvenile Fin whaleaposs cause of death has now been revealed in an update from British Divers Marine Le Rescue. Before the whale was removed from the beach the Big Blue Ocean Cleanup examined the body and confirmed it had been hit by a commercial ship whilst out at sea.The impact caused a bone to puncture the animalaposs lungs, which lead to its death, Essex Live reports. Police, members of Tendring Council, coastguards and Teams from the ocean charity Big Blue Ocean Cleanup all attended the scene. A police cordon was in place near Kingaposs Parade throughout most of Friday while authorities worked together to establish how they would remove the whale. The beach was closed for four miles between Holland-on-Sea and Jaywick to ensure members of the public were not at risk of infection, as The British Divers Marine Le Rescuewarned may be the casepeople came into contact with it. In a statement, the BDMLR said: The animal was already dead when found, BDMLR Medics attended only to gather photographs and other details on its condition that will be passed to our colleagues at the Cetacean Strandings Investigation Programme - UK strandings. We believe it is a fin whale and is approximately ft long, which is rather small for this species as they can grow to over ft, and therefore this animal is a juvenile. Removal of the carcass is the responsibility of the beach owner. In the meantime, we strongly advise people avoid going near it as there is a risk of contracting an infection from contact with its bodily fluids or the body itself. On Saturday authorities worked together to remove the Whale carcass as safely and quickly as possible.Witnesses described seeing sections of the carcass being put into containers, a police cordon remained in place while the animal was removed. On Monday, Tendring District Council issued an update on the tragic incident.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email A -year-old grandmother has just one humble wish after beating coronavirus.Evelyn Bilham, from Hull, tested positive for coronavirus after she was taken to hospital over a fall which left her with two fractured legs.After two weeks on a ward she was moved to a care home, where she was diagnosed with the disease, Hull Live reports.However, she miraculously beat the virus and now all she wants is for her new sofa to be delivered. Evelyn was shielding at home in March during the first week of lockdown when she got up to make a cup of tea, fell and fractured both of her legs. Evelyn, was laid helpless on her living room floor waiting for help for three hours. Her family were alerted after the care company became worried when she did not pick up the phone. The care company called her granddaughter, Melanie Maw, who sent her son-in-law to check on Evelyn. Melanie said: My daughter is shielding but her husband went in the car to her house. We thought she had maybe passed away. He let himself in and she was on the floor in a very strange position. Evelyn was taken to hospital and had surgery on one of her knees which was put into a cage to heal. Her other was put in a cast. Melanie said: She was in hospital for two weeks and she tested negative for Covid. She was put in a care home for rehabilitation and a week later we got a phone call to say she had tested positive. Sheaposd had a really serious fall, an operation, sheaposs had a heart scare, Type  diabetes, a leg ulcer and anaemia. I was thinking, aposSheaposs not going to make it through this.apos  Evelyn was taken to the Needler Ward at Dove House Hospice, which was created to help alleviate pressure on Hullaposs hospitals and to help care for Covid patients. The disease has killed over , people across the UK, and  in Hull and East Yorkshire. Melanie said: When my nana got to Dove House she had a high temperature, the cough, nothing tasted right and a few times when we spoke to her we could hear her chest sounded so wet. They put her on oxygen when she was there. She still has a cough. She had been there for four weeks when she tested negative and then last week they moved her back to the care home and she can now say she has beat Covid. Melanie praised her incredible Nana who has been through so much. She said: We have promised her the earth. Sheaposs called me at times and said, aposI donapost want to dieapos and I said aposYou havenapost gone through all you have for this to finish you off.apos Weaposve promised to decorate her bungalow and she wants a new suite. After all sheaposs been through and how poorly she has been she just wants a new suite. She had ordered one and was waiting for it to come before all of this.  All of the hospital nurses, doctors and staff at the hospital, care home and Dove House have all done a fantastic job. Weaposre so grateful. Evelyn will still be recuperating at the care home for a few more weeks while her legs heal, and despite the lockdown she is still able to keep in touch with her loved ones. Melanie said: Theyaposve put her in a lovely big room. The fact that she got Covid and beat it, I just canapost believe it.It has been horrendous, not being able to visit her but the home have got her set up on a portal so she can see us on a video call but she presses all of the wrong buttons and then gets off Facebook totally.She only has to press the answer button but sheaposs managed to end up on YouTube.

The clip shot by a drone shows the -year-old jumper in black swimming shorts leaping from Durdle Door into the shallow water. Two paddle boarders can be seen coming to his rescue and pulling him onto a large inflatable unicorn before taking him to shore where he was rushed to Southampton hospital. Flatmates Michael Wiley and Dylan Kirkwood, who rescued the man, told the BBC it took five attempts to find him under the water where he was lying on the seabed ft down. Mr Wiley said: He hit the water so hard that he didnapost even come back up to the surface. Boris Johnson recently lted lockdown restrictions which allowed people in England to drive to any part of the country as long as they did not stay overnight. This is being blamed on hundreds of sunseekers flocking to Durdle Door over the weekend to enjoy the warm weather.Despite safety concerns, the police were not able to close off the beach to the public because it is privately owned by the Lulworth Estate. Following the incidents on Saturday Dorset Council pleaded with visitors not to come to the area, and put up barriers to an access road in the neighbouring coastal village of West Bexington to try and stop them.But visitors parked up away from the area and walked miles to get to the beach. The leader of Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole Council has written to local MPs and the chief constable of Dorset Police to call for stricter travel rules. Councillor Vikki Slade, said she had witnessed first-hand incidents of people failing to adhere to social distancing rules, illegal parking, widespread barbecues and staff facing abuse when going about their work. She said: Three weeks ago, following the Prime Ministeraposs announcement that people could travel wherever they liked as long as they did not stay out overnight, we discussed the possibility of limiting travel distance, she said.We were told clearly that this was not possible. We have even been asked to stop councillors and residents from calling the police when they have concerns about gatherings, groups and breaches. We saw the most awful scenes in Durdle Door with the arrival of two helicopters to deal with the stupidity of people jumping from the top of clfs, cheered and clapped by thousands of beachgoers.

The Sun reports having seen a apossecret blueprintapos to kick start Britainaposs pub trade which has been drawn up by ministers in the Department for Business.Breweries, meanwhile, have ramped up production on kegs of beer - which were stopped at the start of the pandemic to focus on cans and bottles - the newspaper said. The aim is reportedly to deliver  million pints-worth of booze by June  as hopes continue to rise that UK pubs may open sooner than expected. For updates on coronavirus, follow our live blog HERE.    The Governmentaposs guidelines reportedly include Wetherspoon-style app ordering systems to avoid people queuing at the bar, while tables will be placed two metres apart. And while other European countries are urging their pubs to use screens between tables this is said to not have been included in guidelines for Britain - though screens will be available for staff at the bar. It is also understood pubs with outdoor beer gardens could open first as part of a two-stage process. Pub trade bodies are currently pleading with the Government to minimise the two metre distancing rule to just one, with many boozers too small to make re-opening worthwhile under current guidelines.This still remains a sticking point, Mr Johnson has admitted, but said work was being done to try and reduce the recommended distance. The boss of British Beer and Pub Associationhas said more than three-quarters of pubs could reopensocial distancing rules were relaxed to one metre.  Chief executive Emma McClarkin warnedthe two-metre guidance remains, just one-third could reopen their doors and many would face further financial misery and ruin.However, a study published in medical journal The Lancet this week suggests cutting social distancing to within m could increase the likelihood of coronavirustransmission by more than four. Many pubs have been taking advantage of recent hot weather and a loosening of the lockdown restrictions to offer takeaway drinks.

title: summer holidays back cards relaxation
story: NewsSummer holidays back on the cards as relaxation of quarantine rules consideredTravel bosses have warned against forcing UK arrivals into quarantine for two weeks and instead pushed for air bridges with  countries where coronavirus is under control, including Spain, Portugal and GreeceShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical Correspondent:,  JUN NewsSummer holidays are back on the cards as the Government considers relaxing quarantine rules " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailSizzling temperatures and packed beaches put people in the holiday mood today – just as their chances of a summer getaway started to look up. Health Secretary Matt Hancock said the Government was considering relaxing border quarantine rules before they had even come into force. As travel bosses warned forcing UK arrivals into quarantine for two weeks would be a “disaster”, airlines pressed for “air bridges” with  countries where the virus is under control, including Spain, Portugal and Greece. Travellers ing from those nations would not have to isolate.PM Boris Johnson is pressing ahead with border quarantine plans as of Monday, despite a growing backlash.But No confirmed the rules will be reviewed after three weeks, which could lead to exemptions for some popular holiday destinations. And it would be in time for school holidays. At tonight’s No briefing, Mr Hancock said he was growing “more optimistic” about the prospect of Brits taking holidays abroad this year. But he said: “Clearly the number one priority is keeping the public safe. “That is the overriding principle and it has been throughout this.” Later Transport Secretary Grant Shapps said: “These measures will be reviewed every few weeks, and we are working to see how we can introduce agreements with other countries when safe to do so, so we can go abroad and tourists can come here.” George Morgan-Grenville, CEO of tour firm Red Savannah, accused the Government of “ignoring the devastation” the quarantine plan would cause.  He said: “By pursuing its quarantine plans without due regard for the economic consequences, the Government is choosing to ignore the devastation it will cause to companies, to employment and to the lives of all those whose jobs will be lost. “The quarantine measures are a blunt weapon which will bring only economic disaster.” EasyJet today revealed it plans to resume flights on as many as half of its routes by the end of July, and almost a quarter of Majorca’s , hotels expect to reopen next month, something local tourism chiefs said was an “unthinkable turnaround” from a month ago. At the end of June, , German tourists will be invited to the island to test new safety protocols. And many Brits are still planning a  getaway, a poll suggests. More than half said they still intended to go on holiday later this year, despite Foreign Office guidelines advising against all-but-essential travel overseas. More than % of the , people quizzed by travel insurance provider Just Travel Cover had not been put off travelling abroad by the pandemic, despite more than half having holiday plans cancelled. Andrew Jackson, MD of the insurance broker, said: “This survey gives us reason to be optimistic.”  Home Secretary Priti Patel is expected to unveil full details of the quarantine plan in Parliament today . Early reports suggest people heading for quarantine will be allowed to take public transport and go outside for food shopping. The PM’s spokesman said: “I think there will be a limited set of exemptions, just as there was during the nationwide lockdown...they need urgent medical treatment, support from social services, food or medicine which they cannot get delivered, or to attend a funeral of a close relative.” He said air bridges were “something the Government is looking at”. Policy was focused on stopping “imported cases of this virus” and, he said, “one of the most devastating things which could happen to the economy is to have a second spike”.  The Home Office said people arriving in Britain would be contacted at random to ensure they are following orders – with rulebreakers facing a £, fine. Testing chief Professor John Newton said rules could be easedthe Test and Trace system was successful. He said: “If travellers are able to be tested and self-isolate in response to contact tracing just like a domestic new case, that would be another way of dealing with it. “At the moment caution has won the day.”
